elements.content: Covalent polymerization of contrived molecular building blocks leads to porous organic polymers (POPs) with intrinsic microporosity. Leveraging the results of our extensive investigations with molecular systems based on twisted biaryl scaffold as applied to metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), we envisioned that the Fridel-Crafts polyalkylation of the 2,2′,6,6′-tetramethylbiphenyl core with α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene should lead to a hypercrosslinked polymer with assured porosity. Furthermore, sulfonation of the latter in a postsynthetic fashion was surmised to yield a POP grafted with sulfonic acid groups for catalysis. Indeed, the polyalkylation of tetramethylbiphenyl led to a highly porous POP (MeBP) with a BET surface area of 1277 m2 g–1. Also, its sulfonated derivative (MeBP@H) exhibited a surface area of 766 m2 g–1, as determined by N2 sorption analysis. Polymer MeBP@H with palpable porosity and endowed with Bronsted acid sites installed through sulfonation was explored for the heterogeneous catalysis of cyclocondensation and cycloaddition reactions in a recyclable fashion. We show that MeBP@H exhibits exceptionally high catalytic activity in the synthesis of a wide variety of photochromic diaryl­benzo­pyrans/napththo­pyrans and pharmacologically relevant triazoles at room temperature. Diverse functional groups are shown to be tolerated in both condensation and cycloaddition reactions. The catalyst is found to be efficient for the synthesis of triazoles having both electron-rich and electron-poor functionalities. Although a variety of methods are known in the literature for the synthesis of both diaryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans and triazoles, MeBP@H allows the reactions to be conducted in shorter reaction times and very cleanly, leading to the isolation of products with high operational simplicity. The catalyst can be isolated back by filtration and recycled; indeed, MeBP@H is shown to be recycled for at least 10 catalytic cycles for both reactions without any loss of efficiency. Additionally, MeBP and MeBP@H are found to exhibit higher uptake capacities for CO2 and C2H2 over N2 at 298 K and inverse uptake capacity for C2H2 over CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Covalent polymerization
of contrived molecular building blocks
leads to porous organic polymers (POPs) with intrinsic microporosity.
Leveraging the results of our extensive investigations with molecular
systems based on twisted biaryl scaffold as applied to metal−organic
frameworks (MOFs) and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), we envisioned
that the Fridel-Crafts polyalkylation of the 2,2′,6,6′-tetramethylbiphenyl
core with α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene
should lead to a hypercrosslinked polymer with assured porosity. Furthermore,
sulfonation of the latter in a postsynthetic fashion was surmised
to yield a POP grafted with sulfonic acid groups for catalysis. Indeed,
the polyalkylation of tetramethylbiphenyl led to a highly porous POP
(MeBP) with a BET surface area of 1277 m2 g–1. Also, its sulfonated derivative (MeBP@H) exhibited a surface area of 766 m2 g–1, as determined by N2 sorption analysis. Polymer MeBP@H with palpable porosity and endowed with Bronsted acid
sites installed through sulfonation was explored for the heterogeneous
catalysis of cyclocondensation and cycloaddition reactions in a recyclable
fashion. We show that MeBP@H exhibits exceptionally high
catalytic activity in the synthesis of a wide variety of photochromic diaryl­benzo­pyrans/napththo­pyrans and pharmacologically
relevant triazoles at room temperature. Diverse functional groups
are shown to be tolerated in both condensation and cycloaddition reactions.
The catalyst is found to be efficient for the synthesis of triazoles
having both electron-rich and electron-poor functionalities. Although
a variety of methods are known in the literature for the synthesis
of both diaryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans and triazoles, MeBP@H allows the reactions to be conducted in shorter reaction
times and very cleanly, leading to the isolation of products with
high operational simplicity. The catalyst can be isolated back by
filtration and recycled; indeed, MeBP@H is shown to be
recycled for at least 10 catalytic cycles for both reactions without
any loss of efficiency. Additionally, MeBP and MeBP@H are found to exhibit higher uptake capacities for CO2 and C2H2 over N2 at 298
K and inverse uptake capacity for C2H2 over
CO2.

elements.content: The past few years have witnessed a revolution in the field of porous materials with permanent porosity. The latter are applicable in gas adsorption and separation, sensing, catalysis, and development of supercapacitors due to their ability to interact with guest species at the surface as well as within the bulk. In recent years, infinitely extended and hydrothermally stable porous organic polymers (POPs), formed by covalent polymerization, have been found to show high surface areas and exotic properties, thus generating an upsurge of interest. Myriad organic building blocks with diverse structures can permit the development of POPs with tunable porosity for various applications stated above. In general, POPs are classified into different types, which include hypercrosslinked polymers (HCPs with conspicuous swelling and superb stability attributes), polymers with intrinsic microporosity (PIMs composed of rigid polymer chains), porous aromatic frameworks (PAFs exhibiting superhydrophobicity), and covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs with hydrophilic attributes). The design and synthesis of POPs entail the polymerization of one or more monomeric units by templation or otherwise. Because of the kinetically controlled polymerization, POPs lack pore periodicity. Several classes of reactions such as condensations, free-radical polymerizations, thermal/chemical substitution reactions, and Friedel−Crafts reactions have been exploited to access diverse POPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The past few years
have witnessed a revolution in the field of
porous materials with permanent porosity. The latter are applicable
in gas adsorption and separation, sensing, catalysis, and development of supercapacitors due to their
ability to interact with guest species at the surface as well as within
the bulk. In recent years, infinitely extended and hydrothermally stable porous
organic polymers (POPs), formed by covalent polymerization, have been
found to show high surface areas and exotic properties, thus generating
an upsurge of interest. Myriad organic building blocks with diverse
structures can permit the development of POPs with tunable porosity
for various applications stated above. In general, POPs are classified into different types,
which include hypercrosslinked polymers (HCPs with conspicuous swelling and superb stability attributes),
polymers with intrinsic microporosity (PIMs composed
of rigid polymer chains), porous aromatic frameworks (PAFs exhibiting
superhydrophobicity), and covalent triazine
frameworks (CTFs with hydrophilic attributes). The design and synthesis of POPs entail the polymerization
of one or more monomeric units by templation or otherwise. Because
of the kinetically controlled polymerization, POPs lack pore periodicity.
Several classes of reactions such as condensations, free-radical polymerizations,
thermal/chemical substitution reactions, and Friedel−Crafts
reactions have been exploited to access diverse POPs.

elements.content: Insofar as catalysis is concerned, there is an incessant quest to develop ecofriendly and metal-free heterogeneous catalysts that incorporate the advantages of conventional heterogeneous catalysts, i.e., high catalytic activity through large surface area, reusability, facile separation, etc., and preclude disadvantages such as the leaching of catalyst during reactions. In this regard, carbonaceous catalysts, which are heterogeneous and metal-free and are largely made up of elements such as C, H, N, O, and S have garnered colossal interest due to the fact that they are ecologically viable, stable, and noncorrosive to conform to the requirements of sustainable development in terms of environmental pollution and energy conservation. Incidentally, there are only a few metal-free heterogeneous catalysts reported with catalytic performances comparable to those of the metal-containing ones. Among various metal-free heterogeneous catalysts, functionalized POPs have emerged as a unique class of exotic materials as heterogeneous supports for catalysis. HCPs are a subclass of POPs which possess high surface areas, exceptional physicochemical stability, a chemical environment of choice, and variable pore size and permit ready incorporation of different functional groups through postsynthetic modification.
elements.clean_text:
Insofar as catalysis is concerned, there is an incessant
quest
to develop ecofriendly and metal-free heterogeneous catalysts that
incorporate the advantages of conventional heterogeneous catalysts,
i.e., high catalytic activity through large surface area, reusability,
facile separation, etc., and preclude disadvantages such as the leaching
of catalyst during reactions. In this
regard, carbonaceous catalysts, which are heterogeneous and metal-free
and are largely made up of elements such as C, H, N, O, and S have
garnered colossal interest due to the fact that they are ecologically
viable, stable, and noncorrosive to conform to the requirements of
sustainable development in terms of environmental pollution and energy
conservation. Incidentally, there are only a few metal-free heterogeneous
catalysts reported with catalytic performances comparable to those
of the metal-containing ones. Among various metal-free heterogeneous
catalysts, functionalized POPs have emerged as a unique class of exotic
materials as heterogeneous supports for catalysis. HCPs are a subclass of POPs which possess high surface
areas, exceptional physicochemical stability, a chemical environment
of choice, and variable pore size and permit ready incorporation of
different functional groups through postsynthetic modification.

elements.content: In our extensive investigations on the development of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) by de novo molecular design, we have shown that molecular systems built on a twisted biaryl core can readily be 4-fold functionalized, leading to materials with assured porosity. Leveraging this attribute, we have herein developed a highly porous organic polymer (i.e., MeBP) based on a 2,2′,6,6′-tetramethylbiphenyl core by employing Fridel-Crafts polyalkylation. The porous polymer was subjected to sulfonation in a postsynthetic scenario to yield a POP grafted with sulfonic acid groups (i.e., MeBP@H).
elements.clean_text:
In our extensive investigations on the
development of metal−organic
frameworks (MOFs) by de novo molecular design, we have shown that molecular
systems built on a twisted biaryl core can readily be 4-fold functionalized,
leading to materials with assured porosity. Leveraging this attribute, we have herein developed a highly porous
organic polymer (i.e., MeBP) based on a 2,2′,6,6′-tetramethylbiphenyl
core by employing Fridel-Crafts polyalkylation. The porous polymer
was subjected to sulfonation in a postsynthetic scenario to yield
a POP grafted with sulfonic acid groups (i.e., MeBP@H).

elements.content: Crystalline metal-free acid catalysts play a key role in the petroleum refinery industry for continuous throughput and efficient separations, aside from other applications. However, they fail to meet catalytic performance comparable to that of the organic molecular acids. In general, the rigid nature of the solid surface precludes efficient accessibility of the acidic sites over the solid surface, a requirement for superacidity. There is thus a growing need to develop solid supports that not only allow efficient grafting of a large number of acidic sites over the surface but also facilitate proton transfer with ease. We have shown that MeBP@H can be readily exploited for the synthesis of several photochromic diaryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans and pharmacologically relevant triazoles. Apart from the catalytic activity, it is also shown that both sulfonated and precursor nonsulfonated POPs exhibit selective sorption of acetylene (C2H2) and carbondioxide (CO2) over nitrogen (N2) at 298 K.
elements.clean_text:
Crystalline metal-free acid catalysts play a key role in
the petroleum
refinery industry for continuous throughput and efficient separations,
aside from other applications. However,
they fail to meet catalytic performance comparable to that of the
organic molecular acids. In general,
the rigid nature of the solid surface precludes efficient accessibility
of the acidic sites over the solid surface, a requirement for superacidity. There is thus a growing need to develop solid supports that not
only allow efficient grafting of a large number of acidic sites over
the surface but also facilitate proton transfer with ease. We have shown that MeBP@H can be readily exploited for the synthesis of several
photochromic diaryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans and
pharmacologically relevant triazoles. Apart from the catalytic activity,
it is also shown that both sulfonated and precursor nonsulfonated
POPs exhibit selective sorption of acetylene (C2H2) and carbondioxide (CO2) over nitrogen (N2) at 298 K.

elements.content: Hypercrosslinked porous organic polymers (HCPs) (i.e., MeBP and OMeBP) were synthesized by FeCl3-mediated Friedel−Crafts polyalkylation reactions of the corresponding monomers (i.e., 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methyl­biphenyl (MeM) and 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methoxy­biphenyl (OMeM)), with α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene (DCX) (cf. ). MeBP and OMeBP were isolated as light-brown solid materials, which were found to be insoluble in common organic solvents. The monomers used for the synthesis of targeted polymers (i.e., MeM and OMeM ) were prepared by following reported protocols that involve the FeCl3-mediated oxidative dimerization of 2,6-dimethylphenyl magnesium bromide and 2,6-dimethoxyphenyl lithium, respectively (cf. Schemes S1 and S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results
and Discussion
Synthesis and Characterization of MeBP and MeBP@H

Hypercrosslinked porous organic
polymers (HCPs)
(i.e., MeBP and OMeBP) were synthesized
by FeCl3-mediated Friedel−Crafts polyalkylation
reactions of the corresponding monomers (i.e., 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methyl­biphenyl
(MeM) and 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methoxy­biphenyl
(OMeM)), with α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene (DCX) (cf. ). MeBP and OMeBP were isolated as light-brown solid materials, which were found to
be insoluble in common organic solvents. The monomers used for the
synthesis of targeted polymers (i.e., MeM
 and OMeM
) were prepared by following reported protocols that involve the
FeCl3-mediated oxidative dimerization of 2,6-dimethylphenyl
magnesium bromide and 2,6-dimethoxyphenyl lithium, respectively (cf. Schemes S1 and S2).

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Synthesis of <bold>MeBP</bold>, <bold>OMeBP</bold>, and <bold>MeBP@H</bold>
</title>
</caption>

</fig>
elements.clean_text:
1

Synthesis of MeBP, OMeBP, and MeBP@H

elements.content: To confirm the successful formation of the polymers from monomeric building blocks with twisted geometry (i.e., MeBP and OMeBP), the porosity of the resultant polymers was investigated through BET surface area analysis (cf. Figure S1). As can be seen, polymer MeBP obtained from MeM exhibited the highest BET surface area of 1277 m2 g–1 compared to that of OMeBP accessed from OMeM; the BET surface area of the latter was found to be 742 m2 g–1, vide infra. These polymers were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopic analyses (cf. Figure S2). The FT-IR spectra of the polymers showed stretching absorptions at 2922 cm–1 for MeBP and at 2925 cm–1 for OMeBP, which are ascribed to C–H stretches due to methylene groups, suggesting that the basic cross-linker (i.e., DCX) is linked to the monomeric units in the polymerization process. Furthermore, the FT-IR spectra reveal absorptions at 1606, 1447, and 1379 cm–1 for MeBP and at 1608, 1453, and 1295 cm–1 for OMeBP corresponding to the stretching modes of aromatic CC, the vibrational coupling of CH2, and the bending mode of CH3 groups, respectively (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
To confirm the successful formation of the polymers
from monomeric
building blocks with twisted geometry (i.e., MeBP and OMeBP), the porosity of the resultant polymers was investigated
through BET surface area analysis (cf. Figure S1). As can be seen, polymer MeBP obtained from MeM exhibited the highest BET surface area of 1277 m2 g–1 compared to that of OMeBP accessed
from OMeM; the BET surface area of the latter was found
to be 742 m2 g–1, vide infra. These polymers were characterized by Fourier-transform infrared
(FT-IR) spectroscopic analyses (cf. Figure S2). The FT-IR spectra of the polymers showed stretching absorptions
at 2922 cm–1 for MeBP and at 2925 cm–1 for OMeBP, which are ascribed to C–H
stretches due to methylene groups, suggesting that the basic cross-linker
(i.e., DCX) is linked to the monomeric units in the polymerization
process. Furthermore, the FT-IR spectra reveal absorptions at 1606,
1447, and 1379 cm–1 for MeBP and at
1608, 1453, and 1295 cm–1 for OMeBP corresponding to the stretching modes of aromatic CC, the
vibrational coupling of CH2, and the bending mode of CH3 groups, respectively (Figure S2).

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the polymers obtained in many experiments under similar experimental conditions showed similar gas adsorptions, vindicating the reproducibility of polymers in terms of their homogeneity and purity. We envisioned that grafting sulfonic acid functionalities to the highly porous polymers must provide a much-needed advantage over molecular arylsulfonic acids for catalytic activity, recyclability, and other applications. Thus, we chose polymer MeBP with a higher BETsurface area than OMeBP to graft sulfonic acid functionalities to provide access to MeBP@H, which could be explored for highly efficient sulfonic acid-mediated catalysis. Thus, MeBP was subjected to a sulfonation reaction using ClSO3H in dry DCM at room temperature in a postsynthetic fashion to afford sulfonic acid-derived HCP (i.e., MeBP@H). The latter exhibited a substantially lower BET surface area of 766 m2g–1 (Figure S1). The postsynthetic incorporation of sulfonic acid was also evidenced by the FT-IR spectrum, which reveals absorptions at 3443, 1175, and 1022 cm–1 corresponding to the stretching frequencies of OH, SO3, and SO, respectively (cf. and Figure S2). Additionally, the presence of sulfur was established by a number of analyses, which include energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) SEM (Figure S3), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Figure S4), and elemental analysis (Table S1), vide infra. The thermal robustness of the polymers (i.e., MeBP and MeBP@H) was examined by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA), which show that the polymers are stable up to 350 °C. Beyond this temperature, they were found to decompose with continuous weight loss (cf. Figure S5). The initial weight loss in the TGA of MeBP is attributed to the loss of solvent molecules entrapped in the pores of the polymeric network. The weight loss at around 200 °C in MeBP@H is ascribed to the desulfonation of the material, which has been previously well documented for analogous polymers. The surface morphologies of MeBP and MeBP@H were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analyses (cf. ). The SEM analysis of MeBP reveals the cluster morphology of the polymer with a coarse surface and loosely structured irregular nanosized particles that are bound together. The TEM analysis of MeBP also reveals a rough surface and loosely bound nanosized particles (cf. ). SEM of the sulfonic acid-functionalized POP (i.e., MeBP@H) reveals that the cluster morphology of the polymer remains intact after sulfonation with ClSO3H, which was further confirmed by TEM analysis (cf. ). The successful sulfonation of MeBP was also established by CHNS analysis, SEM-EDX, and XPS (cf. Table S1 and Figures S3 and S4). The amount of sulfur incorporated into the POP as determined by XPS, elemental analyses and SEM-EDX was found to be 4.01, 4.81, and 3.27 wt %, respectively (cf. Table S1). Furthermore, XPS analysis also revealed the binding energies corresponding to C 1s (284.2 eV), S 2p (168.2 eV), and O 1s (530.5 eV), validating the presence of sulfonic acid groups (Figure S4).

under similar experimental conditions showed similar gas adsorptions,
vindicating the reproducibility of polymers in terms of their homogeneity
and purity. We envisioned that grafting sulfonic acid functionalities

and other applications. Thus, we chose polymer MeBP with a higher BETsurface area than OMeBP to graft sulfonic acid functionalities to provide access to MeBP@H, which could be explored for highly efficient sulfonic

a sulfonation reaction using ClSO3H in dry DCM at room

HCP (i.e., MeBP@H). The latter exhibited a substantially
lower BET surface area of 766 m2g–1 (Figure S1). The postsynthetic incorporation of
sulfonic acid was also evidenced by the FT-IR spectrum, which reveals

to the stretching frequencies of OH, SO3, and SO,
respectively (cf.  and Figure S2). Additionally, the presence of sulfur was established by
a number of analyses, which include energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX)
SEM (Figure S3), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS, Figure S4), and elemental analysis
(Table S1), vide infra. The thermal robustness of the polymers (i.e., MeBP and MeBP@H) was examined by thermogravimetric analyses
(TGA), which show that the polymers are stable up to 350 °C.
Beyond this temperature, they were found to decompose with continuous
weight loss (cf. Figure S5). The initial

of solvent molecules entrapped in the pores of the polymeric network. The weight loss at around 200 °C in MeBP@H is ascribed to the desulfonation of the material, which

elements.content: SEM images of MeBP (a) and MeBP@H (b) and TEM images of MeBP (c) and MeBP@H (d).
elements.clean_text:
1

SEM images
of MeBP (a) and MeBP@H (b)
and TEM images of MeBP (c) and MeBP@H (d).

elements.content: Prior to the gas sorption analyses, polymers MeBP and MeBP@H were activated by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h to remove any entrapped guest/solvent molecules. Porosity in the activated polymers was investigated by N2 gas sorption analyses at 77 K. The BET surface areas calculated from N2 sorption analyses are 1277 m2 g–1 for MeBP and 766 m2 g–1 for MeBP@H. Clearly, the grafting of sulfonic acid groups decreases the sizes of pores, leading to low pore volumes and hence a perceptible drop in the surface area of MeBP@H. The N2 sorption isotherms of these polymers appear to be a combination of type I and type IV; the steep N2 gas uptake at relatively low pressure (P/P o < 0.1) confirms the microporous nature of the polymers. The gradual increase in the N2 adsorption at higher pressures (P/P o = 0.8–1.0) indicates the existence of mesopores along with micropores, which is also evidenced by the hysteresis at higher pressures (cf. ). The coexistence of micropores and mesopores was further confirmed by pore size distributions, calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT), which reveals the pore sizes in the range of 1.4–4.8 nm; the micropores are centered at 1.4 nm, and mesopores range from 2.6–4.8 nm in both polymers (cf. Figure S6). The micropore surface area, external surface area, and micropore volume are textural parameters derived from N2 sorption isotherms, and these data are collected in .
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Analyses of MeBP and MeBP@H

Prior to the gas sorption analyses,
polymers MeBP and MeBP@H were activated
by heating at 120 °C
under vacuum for 24 h to remove any entrapped guest/solvent molecules.
Porosity in the activated polymers was investigated by N2 gas sorption analyses at 77 K. The BET surface areas calculated
from N2 sorption analyses are 1277 m2 g–1 for MeBP and 766 m2 g–1 for MeBP@H. Clearly, the grafting of
sulfonic acid groups decreases the sizes of pores, leading to low
pore volumes and hence a perceptible drop in the surface area of MeBP@H. The N2 sorption isotherms of these polymers appear to
be a combination of type I and type IV; the steep N2 gas uptake at relatively low pressure (P/P
o < 0.1) confirms the
microporous nature of the polymers. The gradual increase in the N2 adsorption at higher pressures (P/P
o = 0.8–1.0) indicates the existence
of mesopores along with micropores, which is also evidenced by the
hysteresis at higher pressures (cf. ). The coexistence
of micropores and mesopores was further confirmed by pore size distributions,
calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT), which reveals
the pore sizes in the range of 1.4–4.8 nm; the micropores are
centered at 1.4 nm, and mesopores range from 2.6–4.8 nm in
both polymers (cf. Figure S6). The micropore surface area, external surface
area, and micropore volume are textural parameters derived from N2 sorption isotherms, and these data are collected in .

elements.content: Adsorption–desorption isotherms of N2, H2, CO2, and C2H2 of MeBP and MeBP@H at 1 bar. Note that the adsorption and desorption profiles in each case have been shown with filled and open circles, respectively.

isotherms of N2, H2, CO2, and C2H2 of MeBP and MeBP@H at 1 bar. Note that the adsorption
and desorption profiles in each case have been shown with filled and
open circles, respectively.

[^b]: Micropore surface area, micropore volume, and external surface area calculated using the t-plot method from the N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K.

elements.content: In general, in porous materials that contain both mesopores and micropores, the mesopores can act as transport channels within the polymeric matrix to facilitate the transfer of mass during the gas uptake process, while micropores enhance the interaction between the walls of polymer and gas molecules. Because the POPs contain both mesopores and micropores, they are expected to adsorb CO2. The CO2 uptake capacities of MeBP and MeBP@H were investigated at 195 K, which showed an impressive uptake of 410 and 267 ccg–1, respectively (cf. ). Furthermore, the analysis of CO2 sorption at 298 K and 1 bar revealed that these polymers selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 (cf. ). The initial slope calculations lead to selectivities of 10.6 and 12.4 for CO2 over N2 for MeBP and MeBP@H, respectively (cf. and Figures S7 and S8). The marginally higher selectivity for MeBP@H for the uptake of CO2 over N2 compared to that of MeBP is presumably due to the presence of polar −SO3H groups in the former, which interact strongly with CO2 (cf. ). Spurred by the results observed with CO2 adsorption, the ability of POPs to adsorb C2H2 was undertaken. Unsurprisingly, both polymers showed unusually high uptake for C2H2 over N2 at 298 K ().

In general, in porous materials
that contain both mesopores and
micropores, the mesopores can act as transport channels within the
polymeric matrix to facilitate the transfer of mass during the gas
uptake process, while micropores enhance the interaction between the
walls of polymer and gas molecules. Because the POPs contain both
mesopores and micropores, they are expected to adsorb CO2. The CO2 uptake capacities
of MeBP and MeBP@H were investigated at
195 K, which showed an impressive uptake of 410 and 267 ccg–1, respectively (cf. ). Furthermore, the analysis of CO2 sorption at
298 K and 1 bar revealed that these polymers selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 (cf. ). The initial slope calculations lead to
selectivities of 10.6 and 12.4 for CO2 over N2 for MeBP and MeBP@H, respectively (cf.  and Figures S7 and S8). The marginally higher selectivity for MeBP@H for the uptake of CO2 over N2 compared to that of MeBP is presumably due to the presence
of polar −SO3H groups in the former, which interact
strongly with CO2 (cf. ). Spurred by the results observed with CO2 adsorption, the ability of POPs to adsorb C2H2 was undertaken. Unsurprisingly, both polymers showed unusually
high uptake for C2H2 over N2 at 298
K ().

elements.content:
Gas Sorption Data of <bold>MeBP</bold> and <bold>MeBP@H</bold> H2 C2H2 CO2 N2 POP 77 K 298 K 195 K 298 K 77 K 298 K C2H2vs N2 CO2vs N2 C2H2vs CO2 C2H2/N2 CO2/N2 MeBP 146 64.6 410 43.9 718 5.5 18.7 10.6 1.7 11.7 7.9 MeBP@H 120 51.4 267 41.3 402 4.8 18.6 12.4 1.5 10.7 8.6

All gas uptake values are expressed in ccg–1.

The determination of selectivity factors was based on single-component isotherms.

Uptake ratio.

The initial slope calculations revealed that MeBP and MeBP@H show excellent selectivity for C2H2 over N2 by factors of 18.7 and 18.6, respectively (cf. and Figures S7 and S8). This exceptional higher uptake of C2H2 compared to that of N2 at 298 K and 1 bar may be attributed to C–H····π interactions between C2H2 and phenyl groups present in the polymeric matrix. The results of the selective adsorption of C2H2 and CO2 over N2 are summarized in . A comparison of the results for CO2 and C2H2 shows that POPs MeBP and MeBP@H exhibit a marginally higher uptake capacity for C2H2 over CO2 despite the fact that both molecules have a similar kinetic diameter of 3.3 Å. Understandably, C–H···π interactions between C2H2 molecules and phenyl groups present in the polymeric matrix are more prominent than π–π interactions between CO2 and phenyl groups of the polymeric matrix (cf. and ). A similar investigation involving hydrogen sorption for both polymers revealed that MeBP captures 146 ccg–1 of H2, while MeBP@H captures 120 ccg–1 of H2 at 77 K (cf. ).

1 bar may be attributed to C–H····π
interactions between C2H2 and phenyl groups
present in the polymeric matrix. The results of the selective adsorption

molecules have a similar kinetic diameter of 3.3 Å. Understandably,
C–H···π interactions between C2H2 molecules and phenyl groups present in the polymeric

elements.content: High porosity that enables free mass transport within the pores and a large number of acidic sites due to high surface area were a motivation to explore the application of MeBP@H for acid-mediated catalysis. Among several methods available for the synthesis of well-known photochromic diarylbenzopyrans/naphthopyrans, the cyclocondensation reaction of propargyl alcohols with phenols in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) or pyridinium p-toluenesulfonate (PPTS) as a catalyst is the most widely applied one. In fact, this method requires longer reaction times and high reaction temperatures and often leads to the required products in rather low yields. We thus envisaged the possibility of conducting an acid-mediated cyclocondensation of phenols with propargyl alcohols in the presence of MeBP@H as a catalyst under heterogeneous reaction conditions; in general, the reactions under heterogeneous conditions using sulfonic acids are known to be clean, leading to products in good yields under ambient reaction conditions. To begin with, the cyclocondensation of 1,1-di­phenyl­propyn-1-ol (1.2 mmol) with 2-naphthol (1.0 mmol) was investigated as a model reaction for the synthesis of 3,3-diphenyl-3H-benzo­[f]­chromene. This reaction was performed using MeBP@H (2.5 mg) in DCM (3 mL), leading to the desired product in 73% yield within 2 h (Table S2). To improve the yield of the reaction, the optimization of several conditions involving change of solvent, temperature, and catalyst loading was carried out. Accordingly, the following conditions were deemed best for the synthesis of photochromic diphenylnapththopyran: 2-naphthol (1.0 mmol), 1,1-di­phenyl­propyn-1-ol (1.2 mmol), and MeBP@H (5.0 mg) in DCM (3 mL) at rt for 2 h­(cf. Table S2). Under these conditions, the synthesis of a number of photochromic di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans could be readily accomplished conveniently in very good isolated yields (78–95%); see . As can be seen in , a wide variety of functionalized phenols/naphthols and differently functionalized propargyl alcohols are well tolerated under the conditions of the cyclocondensations mediated by MeBP@H. A noteworthy exception is the reaction of 1-(4-(tert-butyl­di­methyl­silyl­oxy)­phenyl)-1-phenyl­prop-2-yn-1-ol with 3,5-dimethyl­phenol, which was found to be sluggish, yielding the corresponding product in rather poor yield (54%) ().
elements.clean_text:
MeBP@H for Acid-Mediated Heterogeneous
Catalysis
High porosity that enables free mass transport
within the pores
and a large number of acidic sites due to high surface area were a
motivation to explore the application of MeBP@H for acid-mediated
catalysis. Among several methods available for the synthesis of well-known
photochromic diarylbenzopyrans/naphthopyrans, the cyclocondensation reaction of propargyl alcohols with phenols
in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA)
or pyridinium p-toluenesulfonate (PPTS) as a catalyst
is the most widely applied one. In fact, this method requires longer reaction times
and high reaction temperatures and often leads to the required products
in rather low yields. We thus envisaged the possibility of conducting
an acid-mediated cyclocondensation of phenols with propargyl alcohols
in the presence of MeBP@H as a catalyst under heterogeneous
reaction conditions; in general, the reactions under heterogeneous
conditions using sulfonic acids are known to be clean, leading to
products in good yields under ambient reaction conditions. To begin with, the cyclocondensation of 1,1-di­phenyl­propyn-1-ol
(1.2 mmol) with 2-naphthol (1.0 mmol) was investigated as a model
reaction for the synthesis of 3,3-diphenyl-3H-benzo­[f]­chromene.
This reaction was performed using MeBP@H (2.5 mg) in
DCM (3 mL), leading to the desired product in 73% yield within 2 h
(Table S2). To improve the yield of the
reaction, the optimization of several conditions involving change
of solvent, temperature, and catalyst loading was carried out. Accordingly,
the following conditions were deemed best for the synthesis of photochromic
diphenylnapththopyran: 2-naphthol (1.0 mmol), 1,1-di­phenyl­propyn-1-ol
(1.2 mmol), and MeBP@H (5.0 mg) in DCM (3 mL) at rt for
2 h­(cf. Table S2). Under these conditions,
the synthesis of a number of photochromic di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/naphtho­pyrans
could be readily accomplished conveniently in very good isolated yields
(78–95%); see . As can be seen in , a wide variety of functionalized phenols/naphthols
and differently functionalized propargyl alcohols are well tolerated
under the conditions of the cyclocondensations mediated by MeBP@H. A noteworthy exception is the reaction of 1-(4-(tert-butyl­di­methyl­silyl­oxy)­phenyl)-1-phenyl­prop-2-yn-1-ol
with 3,5-dimethyl­phenol, which was found to be sluggish, yielding
the corresponding product in rather poor yield (54%) ().

elements.content:
<bold>MeBP@H</bold>-Catalyzed Synthesis of Photochromic Diphenylbenzopyrans/Naphthopyrans from Phenols/Naphthols and Propargyl Alcohols<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref> <sup>,</sup> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn2"></xref>

Unless otherwise noted, the reactions were conducted as follows: phenol/naphthol (1.0 mmol), propargyl alcohol (1.2 mmol), MeBP@H (5.0 mg), and DCM (3 mL).

Yield and TON are given in parentheses, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Table 3

**MeBP@H**-Catalyzed Synthesis of Photochromic Diphenylbenzopyrans/Naphthopyrans from Phenols/Naphthols and Propargyl Alcohols[^a][^b]

![GRAPHIC-d7e1531-autogenerated](ap0c00225_0004.eps)

[^a]: Unless otherwise noted, the reactions were conducted as follows: phenol/naphthol (1.0 mmol), propargyl alcohol (1.2 mmol), **MeBP@H** (5.0 mg), and DCM (3 mL).
[^b]: Yield and TON are given in parentheses, respectively.

elements.content: Buoyed by the facile process by which the photochromic diarylpyrans could be synthesized using MeBP@H, we explored its effectiveness for the synthesis of pharmacologically relevant triazoles. The initial screening of the cycloaddition reaction was carried out with β-nitrostyrene (1.0 mmol) and NaN3 (1.5 mmol) by employing 10.0 mg of MeBP@H as the catalyst (cf. ). The reaction was optimized on the basis of a number of screening experiments (cf. Table S3). Accordingly, the following conditions were found to maximize the yield of the product: β-nitrostyrene (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL) at rt over a period of 1 h. With these established reaction conditions, diverse differently substituted triazoles were synthesized using substituted β-nitroarylolefins (cf. ). Clearly, MeBP@H exhibits remarkable catalytic activity and is quite compatible with the synthesis of both electron-rich and electron-poor triazoles (cf. ).
elements.clean_text:
Buoyed by
the facile process by which the photochromic diarylpyrans
could be synthesized using MeBP@H, we explored its effectiveness
for the synthesis of pharmacologically relevant triazoles. The initial
screening of the cycloaddition reaction was carried out with β-nitrostyrene
(1.0 mmol) and NaN3 (1.5 mmol) by employing 10.0 mg of MeBP@H as the catalyst (cf. ). The reaction was optimized on the basis
of a number of screening experiments (cf. Table S3). Accordingly, the following conditions were found to maximize
the yield of the product: β-nitrostyrene (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL)
at rt over a period of 1 h. With these established reaction conditions,
diverse differently substituted triazoles were synthesized using substituted
β-nitroarylolefins (cf. ). Clearly, MeBP@H exhibits remarkable
catalytic activity and is quite compatible with the synthesis of both
electron-rich and electron-poor triazoles (cf. ).

<bold>MeBP@H-</bold>Catalyzed Synthesis of Triazoles<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t4fn1"></xref> <sup>,</sup> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t4fn2"></xref>

Unless otherwise noted, the reaction conditions were as follows: nitroalkene (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL).

Yield and TON are given in parentheses, respectively.

[^a]: Unless otherwise noted, the reaction conditions were as follows: nitroalkene (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL).

elements.content: To investigate the possibility of the partial solubility of the polymer that leads to the loss of the material, a catalyst filtration test was conducted under standard conditions. The fact that the loss of polymeric material into the solution does not occur was established by the lack of any reaction (cf. Figure S9). At the same time, the recyclability of the catalyst for the synthesis of triazoles as well as photochromic di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/napththo­pyrans was also investigated. It was found that the catalyst is effective even after 10 reaction cycles. To carry out the recycling experiments, the catalyst was recovered by filtration after the completion of the reaction, washed thoroughly with water, ethyl acetate, MeOH, and DCM, dried at 50 °C for 4 h, and re-employed for fresh cycles of reactions (cf. Figures S10 and S11). Furthermore, in order to ensure the morphological integrity of the polymer after 10 catalytic cycles, SEM and TEM analyses of the recycled polymer were performed. The SEM and TEM analyses showed no change in the morphology of the polymer (cf. Figure S12).
elements.clean_text:
To investigate
the possibility of the partial solubility of the
polymer that leads to the loss of the material, a catalyst filtration
test was conducted under standard conditions. The fact that the loss
of polymeric material into the solution does not occur was established
by the lack of any reaction (cf. Figure S9). At the same time, the recyclability of the catalyst for the synthesis
of triazoles as well as photochromic di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/napththo­pyrans
was also investigated. It was found that the catalyst is effective
even after 10 reaction cycles. To carry out the recycling experiments,
the catalyst was recovered by filtration after the completion of the
reaction, washed thoroughly with water, ethyl acetate, MeOH, and DCM,
dried at 50 °C for 4 h, and re-employed for fresh cycles of reactions
(cf. Figures S10 and S11). Furthermore,
in order to ensure the morphological integrity of the polymer after
10 catalytic cycles, SEM and TEM analyses of the recycled polymer
were performed. The SEM and TEM analyses showed no change in the morphology
of the polymer (cf. Figure S12).

elements.content: Hypercrosslinked porous organic polymers (HCPs) (i.e., MeBP and OMeBP) were designed and synthesized starting from monomers with twisted geometry (i.e., MeM and OMeM). Of the two POPs, the former with the highest BET surface area of 1277 m2 g–1 was subjected to postsynthetic sulfonation to provide access to SO3H-supported POPs (i.e., MeBP@H), which could be leveraged for acid-mediated catalysis in a heterogeneous fashion. The composition and porosity of MeBP@H were established by SEM, TEM, XPS, and gas sorption analyses. Both POPs, that is, precursors MeBP and MeBP@H, were found to display selective sorption of CO2 and C2H2 over N2. Porous MeBP@H was exploited as a heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of diverse pharmacologically relevant triazoles and well-known photochromic diarylbenzopyrans/napthopyrans. Both cycloaddition and cyclocondensation reactions that lead to different classes of molecules were found to proceed smoothly in good yields, permitting facile workup and recovery of the catalyst at the end of the reactions. Although several reactions catalyzed by POPs have been reported, cyclocondensation and cycloaddition reactions in the presence of POP catalysts such as those uncovered herein for the synthesis of di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/naptho­pyrans and triazoles are heretofore unknown. Given the ease with which the POPs are synthesized by the Friedel−Crafts polyalkylation and their ready synthetic accessibility, the catalytic performance by MeBP@H is singularly exceptional, and the expedient synthesis of two distinct classes of compounds is compellingly demonstrated.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
Hypercrosslinked porous organic polymers (HCPs) (i.e., MeBP and OMeBP) were designed and synthesized starting from
monomers with twisted geometry (i.e., MeM and OMeM). Of the two POPs, the former with the highest BET surface area
of 1277 m2 g–1 was subjected to postsynthetic
sulfonation to provide access to SO3H-supported POPs (i.e., MeBP@H), which could be leveraged for acid-mediated catalysis
in a heterogeneous fashion. The composition and porosity of MeBP@H were established by SEM, TEM, XPS, and gas sorption
analyses. Both POPs, that is, precursors MeBP and MeBP@H, were found to display selective sorption of CO2 and C2H2 over N2. Porous MeBP@H was exploited as a heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis
of diverse pharmacologically relevant triazoles and well-known photochromic
diarylbenzopyrans/napthopyrans. Both cycloaddition and cyclocondensation
reactions that lead to different classes of molecules were found to
proceed smoothly in good yields, permitting facile workup and recovery
of the catalyst at the end of the reactions. Although several reactions
catalyzed by POPs have been reported, cyclocondensation and cycloaddition
reactions in the presence of POP catalysts such as those uncovered
herein for the synthesis of di­aryl­benzo­pyrans/naptho­pyrans
and triazoles are heretofore unknown. Given the ease with which the
POPs are synthesized by the Friedel−Crafts polyalkylation and
their ready synthetic accessibility, the catalytic performance by MeBP@H is singularly exceptional, and the expedient synthesis
of two distinct classes of compounds is compellingly demonstrated.

elements.content: A dry two-necked, round-bottomed flask was charged with 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methylbiphenyl (MeM) (0.2 g, 0.95 mmol), α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene (DCX) (0.33 g, 1.9 mmol), and dry 1,2-dichloroethane (15 mL, DCE) under N2 atmosphere. Anhydrous FeCl3 (0.92 g, 5.7 mmol) was slowly introduced into the reaction mixture. The latter was gradually heated to 45 °C and stirred for 1 h. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was further held at reflux for 2 days. After the completion of the reaction, the brown solid was filtered and washed thoroughly with 1 M HCl, water, MeOH, and DCM. The resultant requisite polymer MeBP was dried under vacuum at 120 °C for 24 h, with a yield of 0.31 g (79%).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section
General Procedure for the
Synthesis of MeBP


A dry two-necked, round-bottomed
flask was charged with
2,2′,6,6′-tetra­methylbiphenyl (MeM) (0.2 g, 0.95 mmol), α,α′-dichloro-p-xylene (DCX) (0.33 g, 1.9 mmol), and dry 1,2-dichloroethane
(15 mL, DCE) under N2 atmosphere. Anhydrous FeCl3 (0.92 g, 5.7 mmol) was slowly introduced into the reaction mixture.
The latter was gradually heated to 45 °C and stirred for 1 h.
Subsequently, the reaction mixture was further held at reflux for
2 days. After the completion of the reaction, the brown solid was
filtered and washed thoroughly with 1 M HCl, water, MeOH, and DCM.
The resultant requisite polymer MeBP was dried under
vacuum at 120 °C for 24 h, with a yield of 0.31 g (79%).

elements.content: Similarly, the methoxy analog of MeBP (i.e., OMeBP) was synthesized by following the above procedure and by employing 2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy­biphenyl (OMeM) (0.2 g, 0.72 mmol), DCX (0.25 g, 1.46 mmol), and FeCl3 (0.7 g, 4.37 mmol) in dry DCE (15 mL). The desired product was isolated in a quantitative yield of 0.26 g (75%).
elements.clean_text:
Similarly, the methoxy analog of MeBP (i.e., OMeBP) was synthesized by following the above procedure and by employing
2,2′,6,6′-tetra­meth­oxy­biphenyl (OMeM) (0.2 g, 0.72 mmol), DCX (0.25 g, 1.46 mmol),
and FeCl3 (0.7 g, 4.37 mmol) in dry DCE (15 mL). The desired
product was isolated in a quantitative yield of 0.26 g (75%).

elements.content: A 100 mL round-bottomed flask containing a suspension of the MeBP (0.2 g) polymer in dry DCM (50 mL) was cooled to 0 °C for 30 min, and ClSO3H (5 mL) was slowly added dropwise under N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was allowed to stir at rt for 72 h. After the completion of the reaction, the mixture was slowly poured into ice water and the black polymeric material was filtered and washed thoroughly with excess water until the pH of the filtrate reached about 7. The resultant sulfonated polymer (i.e., MeBP@H) was dried at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h and characterized by different analytical techniques.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis
of MeBP@H


A 100
mL round-bottomed flask containing a suspension of
the MeBP (0.2 g) polymer in dry DCM (50 mL) was cooled
to 0 °C for 30 min, and ClSO3H (5 mL) was slowly added
dropwise under N2 atmosphere. Subsequently, the reaction
mixture was allowed to stir at rt for 72 h. After the completion of
the reaction, the mixture was slowly poured into ice water and the
black polymeric material was filtered and washed thoroughly with excess
water until the pH of the filtrate reached about 7. The resultant
sulfonated polymer (i.e., MeBP@H) was dried at 120 °C
under vacuum for 24 h and characterized by different analytical techniques.

processes.amount: until the pH of the filtrate reached about 7

elements.content: The characterization of HCPs was performed by drop-casting a methanolic suspension of MeBP and MeBP@H on the silicon wafer/Cu-coated TEM grid at rt and then drying it under N2 gas atmosphere. Prior to chemical deposition, it is important to clean the surfaces of the silicon wafers thoroughly by sonication in acetone for 20 min, followed by methanol for 15 min, and then by drying under the flow of N2 gas. The films of MeBP and MeBP@H cast on the surfaces of the silicon wafers/Cu-coated TEM grids were examined by different microscopic techniques, namely, SEM, TEM, and XPS under ambient conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Microscopic Analysis of Hypercrosslinked Porous Organic Polymers
The characterization of HCPs was performed by drop-casting a methanolic
suspension of MeBP and MeBP@H on the silicon
wafer/Cu-coated TEM grid at rt and then drying it under N2 gas atmosphere. Prior to chemical deposition, it is important to
clean the surfaces of the silicon wafers thoroughly by sonication
in acetone for 20 min, followed by methanol for 15 min, and then by
drying under the flow of N2 gas. The films of MeBP and MeBP@H cast on the surfaces of the silicon wafers/Cu-coated
TEM grids were examined by different microscopic techniques, namely,
SEM, TEM, and XPS under ambient conditions.

elements.content: A 10 mL round-bottomed flask was charged with phenol/naphthol (1.0 mmol), propargyl alcohol (1.2 mmol), and DCM (3 mL). The resultant mixture was stirred at rt for 15 min under N2 atmosphere. At the end of this period, MeBP@H (5.0 mg) was introduced into the reaction mixture and the stirring was continued for 2 h. After the completion of the reaction as confirmed by TLC analysis, the catalyst was filtered and washed with DCM (10 mL × 2) and ethyl acetate (5 mL × 2). The filtrate was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the crude product was purified by short-pad silica gel column chromatography. For the recyclability of the catalyst, the recovered catalyst was washed thoroughly with water, ethyl acetate, MeOH, and DCM and dried at 50 °C for 4 h.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the
Synthesis of Photochromic Diarylbenzopyrans/Naphthopyrans
A 10 mL round-bottomed flask was charged with phenol/naphthol (1.0
mmol), propargyl alcohol (1.2 mmol), and DCM
(3 mL). The resultant mixture was stirred at rt for 15 min under N2 atmosphere. At the end of this period, MeBP@H (5.0 mg) was introduced into the reaction mixture and the stirring
was continued for 2 h. After the completion of the reaction as confirmed
by TLC analysis, the catalyst was filtered and washed with DCM (10
mL × 2) and ethyl acetate (5 mL × 2). The filtrate was evaporated
under reduced pressure, and the crude product was purified by short-pad
silica gel column chromatography. For the recyclability of the catalyst,
the recovered catalyst was washed thoroughly with water, ethyl acetate,
MeOH, and DCM and dried at 50 °C for 4 h.

elements.content: To a 10 mL round-bottomed flask was added nitroolefin (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL), and the mixture was stirred at rt for 1 h. After the completion of the reaction as confirmed by TLC analysis, the catalyst was filtered and washed thoroughly with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The resultant filtrate was diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL × 3). The combined organic layer was evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was subjected to silica gel column chromatography to isolate the pure product. The recovered catalyst was washed thoroughly with water, ethyl acetate, MeOH, and DCM and dried at 50 °C for 4 h before reusing the same for further catalytic reactions.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for the
Synthesis of Triazole
To
a 10 mL round-bottomed flask was added nitroolefin (1.0 mmol), NaN3 (1.5 mmol), MeBP@H (10.0 mg), and DMF (3 mL),
and the mixture was stirred at rt for 1 h. After the completion of
the reaction as confirmed by TLC analysis, the catalyst was filtered
and washed thoroughly with ethyl acetate (10 mL). The resultant filtrate
was diluted with water and extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL ×
3). The combined organic layer was evaporated under reduced pressure.
The crude residue was subjected to silica gel column chromatography
to isolate the pure product. The recovered catalyst was washed thoroughly
with water, ethyl acetate, MeOH, and DCM and dried at 50 °C for
4 h before reusing the same for further catalytic reactions.

metadata.title:
De Novo Access to SO3H‑Grafted Porous
Organic Polymers (POPs@H): Synthesis of Diarylbenzopyrans/Naphthopyrans
and Triazoles by Heterogeneous Catalytic Cyclocondensation and Cycloaddition
Reactions
